top_categories.workout_context: At 127 miles, Belgian Waffle Ride Cedar City punishes athletes who haven’t trained their body to produce power when glycogen runs low.
Belgian Waffle Ride Cedar City’s 75% gravel/dirt, 25% pavement, playground-type sand sectors demands rapid power changes — surge over obstacles, settle on smoother sections, repeat for hours.
Racing Belgian Waffle Ride Cedar City isn’t just fitness — it’s pacing, fueling, and executing when conditions deteriorate. This workout practices the race itself.
Belgian Waffle Ride Cedar City’s fast-rolling gravel with hidden treachery and competitive field demand explosive aerobic capacity — the ability to respond to surges without blowing up.
Every session at Belgian Waffle Ride Cedar City intensity builds on this aerobic foundation — the endurance base is the soil everything else grows in.
Belgian Waffle Ride Cedar City rewards athletes who can hold sustained power without blowing up — threshold is the engine that drives everything above Zone 2.
Critical power determines how long you can sustain above-threshold efforts at Belgian Waffle Ride Cedar City — a higher CP means more time in the red before failure.
Over-unders train the lactate clearance you’ll need at Belgian Waffle Ride Cedar City when surges push you above threshold and you have to recover while still riding hard.
The G-Spot zone (88–92% FTP) is where you’ll spend the hardest sustained miles of Belgian Waffle Ride Cedar City. Make this intensity feel like home.
At 127 miles, Belgian Waffle Ride Cedar City rewards a massive aerobic engine. This volume work builds the fat-oxidation capacity that keeps you moving when glycogen runs low.
Short, violent efforts are unavoidable at Belgian Waffle Ride Cedar City — climbs demanding 2-minute maximal efforts, surges to close gaps, attacks on fast-rolling gravel with hidden treachery.
Blended sessions combine endurance with intensity spikes — exactly what Belgian Waffle Ride Cedar City’s fast-rolling gravel with hidden treachery delivers on race day.

race_overlay.heat: June in Cedar City, Utah — Early April at 5,600+ ft means below-freezing starts are common. 2024 had 'snowing sideways' pre-race day with freezing temps, high winds, and snow on run-in. Good years warm to 50s-60s°F. Begin heat acclimatization 10–14 days before Belgian Waffle Ride Cedar City — 20–30min sauna sessions or midday rides in full kit. Pre-load sodium 48 hours out. Target 500–750ml/hr with electrolytes on race day. Race-day realities: Dehydration risk once sun and pace pick up.
race_overlay.nutrition: Target 60–80g carbs/hour for Belgian Waffle Ride Cedar City’s 127 miles. Start fueling within the first 30 minutes — early fueling prevents late-race collapse. Bonking at mile 60 is a nutrition failure, not a fitness failure.
race_overlay.altitude: Moderate altitude at Belgian Waffle Ride Cedar City. Arrive 2–3 days early. Reduce intensity expectations by 5–10%. Hydrate aggressively.
race_overlay.terrain: Highly technical terrain at Belgian Waffle Ride Cedar City demands practice on similar surfaces. Ride fast-rolling gravel with hidden treachery at race-day cadence weekly. Expect: 75% gravel/dirt, 25% pavement, playground-type sand sectors, fast ranch roads. Practice cornering, descending, and power delivery on unstable surfaces. Dial in tire pressure before race week — 5 PSI wrong costs you 15+ minutes over 127 miles.

pack_summary: This 10-workout pack focuses on Durability, Gravel Specific, and Race Simulation to prepare you for 127 miles of fast-rolling gravel with hidden treachery in Cedar City, Utah.
